docs.lead_paragraph: ''Enjoy the war,'' says a cynical jokester in ''Film Without a Title,'' one of occupied Germany's groundbreaking movies, made in 1947 but set in wartime Berlin. ''Peacetime will be terrible.'' Even as the crushed nation lay in ruins, with filigrees of bomb-blasted walls silhouetted against gray skies and trains acrawl with refugees, a handful of directors, screenwriters and actors struggled to make sense of their fate, perhaps put a spin on ugly history and create a postwar German cinema.
docs.abstract: Article on post-World War II German movies, now considered embodiment of golden age of German film, in light of upcoming Film Society of Lincoln Center festival; series of 31 films, with war as theme, focuses largely on miseries Germans suffered rather than those they inflicted; highlights; photos; chart (M)

headline.main: A Golden Age Of German Film

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the unhealed sores from World War II is threatening the unity of four countries that have hoped to find their future, soon and as a bloc, in the European Union. Over the last week, Hungary's prime minister, Viktor Orban, called several times for the repeal of the so-called Benes decrees -- the orders issued by Czechoslovakia's post-World War II president, Edvard Benes, that allowed for the expulsion of some three million Germans, as well as tens of thousands of Hungarians, from Czechoslovakia after the war.
docs.abstract: Hungarian Prime Min Viktor Orban calls for repeal of decrees issued by Edvard Benes, Czechoslovakia's postwar president, allowing for expulsion of millions of Germans and Hungarians from Czechoslovakia; Orban says repeal should be condition of European Union membership for Czech Republic and Slovakia, but demand infuriates two countries and puts pressure on partnership with Hungary and Poland (M)

headline.main: Czech Decrees, Dating to 40's, Divide Europe

docs.lead_paragraph: Just a month ago, there was a breakthrough in troubled peace talks here between the rebels and the government. But in the last week, the rebels hijacked a plane and kidnapped a senator, prompting President Andrés Pastrana to take back a big block of land granted to the rebels as a kind of fief free of army intervention. On Saturday, the very day that the president visited this formerly rebel-held town to demonstrate the government's authority, the rebels struck again, kidnapping a high-profile presidential candidate.
docs.abstract: Colombians know that recent hijacking and kidnappings mean intensification of 38-year civil war; most cast blame squarely on rebels, whose string of bombings, kidnappings and other violations eventually led Pres Andres Pastrana to break off negotiations; process that Pastrana began with high hopes in 1998, ceding vast region to rebels as venue for talks, began to unravel almost from beginning; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maoist rebels killed 16 policemen in a morning attack on a police station in Khabre district, 75 miles east of Katmandu, officials said. The toll was the largest for the police since the Himalayan nation's government imposed emergency rule in November. Seven guerrillas were also killed in the battle. Barry Bearak (NYT)
docs.abstract: Maoist rebels kill 16 policemen in Nepal's Khabre district (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An 83-year-old former French general who wrote a book admitting that he had tortured and summarily executed dozens of Algerians during France's brutal colonial war was convicted today ''of trying to justify war'' and fined $6,500. The general, Paul Aussaresses, was pursued not for the acts themselves, which have long been covered by an amnesty, but for telling his unapologetic version of events.
docs.abstract: French court convicts Paul Aussaresses, former French general who admitted in memoirs that he tortured and executed dozens of Algerians during France's brutal colonial war, of trying to justify war and fines him $6,500; convicts president and senior editor of his publishing house of same crime and fines them $13,000; all plan appeal; Aussaresses was pursued not for acts themselves, long covered by amnesty, but for telling unapologetic version of events; photo (M)

headline.main: France Fines General, 83, for Memoir Justifying Algerian War

docs.snippet: Last-ditch efforts to revive broken peace talks between leftist rebels and the government of President Andrés Pastrana failed tonight, setting the stage for a possible army invasion of a huge rebel-held zone in southern Colombia and an escalation...
docs.lead_paragraph: Last-ditch efforts to revive broken peace talks between leftist rebels and the government of President Andrés Pastrana failed tonight, setting the stage for a possible army invasion of a huge rebel-held zone in southern Colombia and an escalation of a 37-year-old conflict. Mr. Pastrana had given a United Nations envoy, James LeMoyne, until Saturday night to find a way to restart negotiations that the president had declared over on Wednesday night in a nationally televised address, citing rebel recalcitrance. But the proposal offered by leaders of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as FARC, was rejected by Mr. Pastrana.
docs.abstract: United Nations envoy James LeMoyne fails in last-ditch bid to revive peace talks between leftist rebels and Colombian government, setting stage for possible army invasion of huge rebel-held zone; Pres Andres Pastrana rejects rebel proposal, televised speech (M)o

headline.main: Colombia's Army Set to Invade Rebel Area as Peace Talks Fail

docs.lead_paragraph: Officially, the tent city that houses war refugees here is called the Southern Point of Provisional Location, and once, that name might actually have fit. But nothing is provisional about the Znamenskoye refugee camp any more. Russia's war against separatist rebels in Chechnya has been going on for more than two years now. For many of 3,021 refugees in this camp, the 85 dun tents staked into the barren Chechen landscape near the Terek River long ago made the shift from haven to home.
docs.abstract: Russia's war against separatist rebels in Chechnya has been going on for more than two years, and thousands of Chechens remain housed in primitive refugee camps, afraid to go home or no longer having home to return to; scene in Znamenskoye camp described; photo (M)

headline.main: Chechen Refugee Camps: Once a Haven, but After Two Years Still Not a Home

docs.lead_paragraph: With one day left in the talks to bring peace to Congo, the government and a main rebel group remained deadlocked today over who would lead an interim government. The talks, which began in late February, appeared on the verge of collapse tonight, as the two sides began blaming each other for a possible failure. If the talks fail, it will be a big setback for African leaders who have tried to end the ruinous four-year war and refocus attention on an economic plan to rebuild Africa.
docs.abstract: Congo government and main rebel group remain deadlocked over who would lead interim government, peace talks, Sun City, South Africa; South African Pres Thabo Mbeki has been meeting with government and representatives of two main rebel groups in bid to bar collapse of talks; Azarias Ruberwa, secretary general of rebel group backed by Rwanda, holds government bid to impose Joseph Kabila as interim leader could end talks; calls for extending talks, move opposed by government (M)

headline.main: Congo Talks Faltering As Final Day Approaches

docs.snippet: Four army officers accused of serious human rights abuses during the violence in East Timor three years ago appeared in a steamy courtroom  here today, the first military defendants to be tried over East Timor after long delays by successive Indon...
docs.lead_paragraph: Four army officers accused of serious human rights abuses during the violence in East Timor three years ago appeared in a steamy courtroom here today, the first military defendants to be tried over East Timor after long delays by successive Indonesian governments in bringing the military to account. The chief of the Indonesian armed forces, Adm. Widodo Adisucipto, and a phalanx of other senior officers sat prominently in the spectators gallery, and members of the red-hatted elite special forces stood around the room. Their presence was announced as a show of solidarity but was interpreted as a signal that the military would not be cowed by the nation's first human rights trials.
docs.abstract: Four Indonesian army officers go on trial in Jakarta on charges of failing to prevent militia forces linked to army from massacring 27 people at Roman Catholic church in Suai, East Timor, in Sept 1999; this is first such trial of military defendants, and it shows that despite little interest among public, Indonesia finally feels that it must stand by promise made in 2000 to establish special court to try those accused of responsibility for killing of civilians before and after 1999 vote for East Timor's independence; photo (M)

headline.main: Indonesia Begins Trials of Military in East Timor Abuses

docs.lead_paragraph: The armed forces went on the offensive today against rebels whose approach to Monrovia, the capital, sent thousands of terrified civilians fleeing and led to the declaration of a state of emergency. The government said the rebels had killed at least 16 people. Tension has gripped Monrovia since rebels attacked Kley, a major road junction 22 miles away, on Thursday, rousing grim memories of the seven-year civil war in the 1990's that killed as many as 200,000 people.
docs.abstract: Armed forces of Liberia go on offensive against rebels, whose approach to Monrovia sends thousands of terrified civilians fleeing; government has declared state of emergency as rebels threaten to attack capital if Pres Charles Taylor does not step down (S)
